comment: Pleasant on the nose, sweet taste, and a slightly hairy finish. I pick up crazy marshmallow on the tongue.
Big nose of sweet paint. Which for those who like scotches such as Laphroig is a good thing. Doesn't benefit from a splash of water. Finishes well but nothing to write home about.
This is awesome stuff. Worth the $89 I spent on it. Nice nose and I love the layers of flavor. Butterscotch into oak into spice with a touch of sweet. I might have to get a 2nd bottle
Pleasant brown sugar nose with notes of apple. Sweet flavor with notes of brown sugar with hints of oak. Peppery finish with notes of sweet oak. Flavors linger for about 30 seconds. Thanks TW.
Interesting, not a regular drinker.   What it says, a mix of a bourbon and rye

Just how I like my American whiskey: Big, savory, and sweet with a heavy dash of barrel notes and a lovely touch of time. This delivers everywhere with vanilla, baked apple, clove, tobacco, brown sugar, leather, caramel, cinnamon, cherry, butter, and a whiff of old books making appearances as that viscous spirit glides along your tongue and lingers. Sumptuous and bold, this was a divine experience.
Very smooth. No burn. Finish is like mild afterburner but remains smooth throughout.

For some people, this is a sensational, first-rate dram.  I wouldn't go quite that far, although it's not unfairly priced at around $80 (and I see it a few places online for closer to $60-65).  The nose is almost hoppy in its herbal, vegetal rye-derived freshness, with some vanilla lending some sweeter notes.  The rye is definitely dominating the blend from the outset.  The palate demonstrates more hybrid characteristics, with an odd tinned pineapple note, but over time the rye again seems to win out and resemble High West Rendezvous Rye.  The finish features barrel char and a great combination of rye spice and bourbon richness.
Baking spice and caramel on the nose. Great mix of rye and bourbon (rye first then bourbon), you can discern notes of both. Autumnal notes. Strong flavors but smooth, nothing is out of place. 1/25/18

2017 release:

Nose: sweet and full of depth of spices

Mouth: light, fruit-laced, and the sweet overall feeling of eating fruit with the skin still on. Very interesting indeed. 

Finish: nice and peppery, nearly no burn. Some sharp oak notes finish this one off. 

A solid 4.25/5. $69.99 in Michigan on 3/25/18
Fruity & floral nose. Carmel, pepper. Peppery finish.
Really smooth, almost no hint of rye to me.  Still a tastey treat tho

My favorite
BBB in 1 Loudoun has it. 
Guys night out 12/29/17
Better than the sum of its parts, but nowhere near worth the price tag.
cinnamon, butterscotch, orange chocolate, gingerbread, walnuts.
Delicious, smooth. Definitely on the rye side with a slight bit of off taste
Great balance of Bourbon and Rye. Rich, velvety and sweet.
MGPI sourced whiskeys, well mixed by HW. Fruit, spicy grassy rye, and oak.

Nose: Baked Apple, hint of chocolate, funk, vanilla
Pallet: Pear, soft oak, vanilla, nutmeg, caramel, honey
Finish: rye spice, astringent, leather, clove
from Park City, Smoky but not overly so, solid

"• A blend of straight Bourbon and Rye whiskeys aged from 10 to 14 years.
• Straight Rye Whiskey: 95% rye, 5% barley malt from MGP & 53% rye, 37% corn, 10% barley malt from MGP
• Straight Bourbon Whiskey: 75% corn, 21% rye, 4% barley malt from MGP"

It starts strong, with a good aroma (a lot of licorice) and flavor, but after sitting for a bit it loses some of that and can become a bit dull. This is a good solid whiskey, overall, but just costs too much for what it delivers.

Nose: Spicy, sweetness (caramel/dark), fruity?
Taste: Bourbon sweetness on the front with firey pepper finish
Zero burn. Very smooth! Sweet, with hints of.... pear? Nice peppery finish, lingers a long time.

2.5 stars. Ok. I’m being unfair. 2.8, maybe 3? I like bourbon. I like rye. I don’t like this bourye. Nice in premise and on paper, but application doesn’t please my pallet (and I’m pretty sure it’s still a fully-sourced and then blended product). Medicinal hint on nose - like all High West products. Not very complex bourbon up front. Smooth rye-ish finish. Not worth ANYWHERE NEAR the $80+ they charge (here in MD). Look elsewhere in the (relative) price point (esp Blanton’s, Macallan 12, Angel’s Envy Rye, even Lot 40; Whistlepig Farmstock isn’t fully sourced anymore and is about $100) to put your hard-earned money to use.

Part of a flight:
Angel’s Envy Bourbon Port Finish (Batch 59I) at 43.3% ABV
High West Bourye (Batch 17L21) at 46% ABV
Prichard’s Double Barreled at 45% ABV

The winner.  
This stuff just gets better with time and water.  The foundation is a very well-aged 10 year old bourbon.  You get that leathery tobacco, cinnamon powder, and red fruits.  The ryes are even more aged – a blend 12-14 years old.  That takes the young rye edge, which I don’t like, away.  It adds some mint and greenness to the bourbon, and never steals the spotlight.  I also get some wine notes, which emerges in the absence of wine finishing, as far as I can tell.  This is very similar to High West’s bespoke Midwinter.
With water, this opens up to reveal white pepper and dark chocolate in a dynamic, lovely finish that lingers for quite a while.
In Maryland, this tends to be cheaper than in other parts of the country.  I found this on sale for $72, and it’s a steal at that price.

MARK: 93/100
Can really taste the combo of sharp rye and sweet bourbon. Comes together extremely well!
A well balanced rye. The burn is nice and not overpowering.
Vanilla, caramel, Christmas spice, toasted coconut ... this beverage makes makes me happy.
Honey, mildy oaky, mapley , a little spicy
Awesome. A beautiful blend. Enjoyed with an Arturo Fuente Hemingway cigar.
Good but too expensive for what it is.
Lots of brown sugar on the nose, which translates to the palate along with a little sweetness and then you get the rye notes on the finish...I like this one, one of the better high west offerings
Definitely still heavy on the rye taste still

Nose: sweet cherry, green wood, slightly floral and grassy, vanilla. 

Perfect blend of bourbon caramel and vanilla sweetness and rye spice. 

Long warm finish of dried fruit and oak.
